Description.val:
The requirement for the RQ-21A Unmanned Aircraft System is defined in a Capability Development Document, dated 18 November 2008 and further defined in the Capability Production Document, dated 15 February 2013.  The RQ-21A program entered the Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase of the acquisition process as an Acquisition Category III program on 26 July 2010. On 19 August 2014 RQ-21A was designated an Acquisition Category II program.

The RQ-21A system provides the Marine Expeditionary Force and subordinate commands (divisions and regiments) and USN Naval Special Warfare (NSW) a dedicated Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance system capable of delivering intelligence products directly to the tactical commander in real time. The RQ-21A system is capable of providing actionable intelligence and communications relay for 12-hour continuous operations per day with a short surge capability of 24-hours continuous operations for l0 days. The system has an operating radius of 50 nautical miles, further extendable through hub and spoke operations. The Air Vehicle is capable of airspeeds up to 80 nautical miles per hour with a service ceiling of 15,000 feet. The Marine Corps will have a quantity of 21 RQ-21 systems procured by FY 2018. The Navy has procured a quantity of 10 RQ-21 systems. There are no future plans to buy more RQ-21 systems at this time, but attrition air vehicles will be procured. 

An RQ-21A system consists of five air vehicles, two ground control stations, modular multi-mission plug and play payloads, one launcher, one recovery system, and support equipment. Standard payloads include a turret mounted Electro Optic/Infrared (EO/IR) camera and a communications relay package with automated identification ship capability, carried in the payload bay.

The RQ-21A system will continue to evolve and upgrade capabilities to satisfy capability shortfalls, new requirements, and reliability, maintainability, and safety issues. Upgraded capabilities may include Navy Command and Control integration, Weapons Integration, Heavy Fuel Engine, Laser Designator, Frequency Agile Communications Relay, Digital Common Data Link, new launch and recovery methods, parts durability and manufacturability, and cyclic refresh of the Electro-Optical/Infrared (EO/IR) camera.

Justification.val: FY 2020 funds are required to retrofit three of the USMC RQ-21A systems and five of the USN Naval Special Warfare (NSW) RQ-21A systems with EO/IR turret upgrade that includes the laser designator capability and optics improvements required for effective identification ($33.445M), perform critical extruded mast upgrade retrofits for four USMC RQ-21A and two USN NSW recovery systems ($3.060M), retrofit twenty-five USN NSW RQ-21 air vehicles (AV) with Unmanned Radio frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite enabling special collection in operational theaters ($18.750M), retrofit eighteen USN NSW RQ-21 AV's with Visual detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload to provide wide-area imaging capability ($3.600M), retrofit fifty USN NSW AV's with Ultra High Frequency (UHF)/Very High Frequency (VHF) transponder communications to provide Identification of Friend or Foe (IFF) capability ($4.100M), and support costs related to both USMC and USN RQ-21 system retrofits ($3.327M).

Name.@footnote: Includes engineering and logistics support required to properly prepare and execute system retrofits in support of both the USMC and USN.

Each Turret Upgrade kit contains 5 turrets to retrofit all 5 air vehicles in a RQ-21A system.  FY 2020 base quantities and funding are for three USMC RQ-21 kits and five USN kits in support of Naval Special Warfare (NSW).  Unit cost increase from FY 2019 to FY 2020 due to upgraded Alticam 14 EO/IR turret which include laser designator capability and optics improvements.

Mast upgrades quantities reflect upgrades per RQ-21A system.  FY2020 base quantities and funding are for four USMC RQ-21 upgrades and two USN NSW RQ-21 upgrades, replacing welded masts which have a 2 1/2 year service life.
VTOL kit includes equipment to retrofit all 5 air vehicles in a RQ-21A system for both USMC and USN NSW systems.
Unmanned Radio Frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite for the RQ-21A enables special collection in Theaters.  FY 2020 Quantity reflects RQ-21 system component - air vehicles.
Visual Detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload for the RQ-21A that provides a wide-area imaging capability for the air vehicle.  FY 2020 Quantity reflects RQ-21 system component - air vehicles.
FY 2020 Quantity reflects RQ-21 system component - air vehicles.

Description.val:
RQ-21 Blackjack Correction of Deficiencies provides near and long term improvements to fielded RQ-21 systems, and focuses on correcting documented deficiencies related to safety, maintainability, and aircraft systems. These modifications and selected component changes are being accomplished by field retrofit performed by contractor artisans and organic support.  In order to meet emerging deficiencies, the airframe and integrated systems must be modified as critical corrections/changes are identified. Funds will be used to manage, prepare, process and incorporate Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and implement those changes in order to sustain and improve RQ-21 system operations. ECPs are implemented to coincide with resources and aircraft availability. These changes provide more robust performance in navigation, weapons, avionics, survivability, maneuverability, maintainability, and mission deployment of the RQ-21 platform. This modification program may be required to provide timely remedial action for any aircraft system, component or structure.

Funding in FY 2019-2021 will modify the current Electro Optical/Infrared camera turret to include a Laser Designator for USMC systems. The retrofit will modify 100% of the USN NSW air vehicles and approximately 60% of all USMC air vehicles with the rest being upgraded through attrition. 

FY 2019-2021 funding will modify the current welded mast sections of the recovery systems with extruded aluminum masts sections which are more durable for the USMC and USN NSW systems. This will strengthen the recovery mast and addresses critical safety concerns. Each RQ-21 system contains one recovery system.

FY 2022-2024 funding supports the modification of the air vehicles to incorporate a Vertical Takeoff and Landing (VTOL) kit.  This retrofit will allow for more expeditionary employment of the RQ-21A system, reduced capture damage and mishap rate, and will reduce the footprint of systems where the capability is employed.  Funds from FY 2022-2024 will retrofit 100% of the USN NSW and approximately 60% of the USMC systems. 

Funds in FY 2020-2023 are required to retrofit USN NSW RQ-21 AV's with Unmanned Radio frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite enabling special collection in operational theaters.

FY 2020-2022 funding will retrofit all USN NSW RQ-21 AV's with Visual detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload to provide wide-area imaging capability to NSW.

Funding in FY 2020 will retrofit all USN NSW RQ-21 AV's with UHF/VHF Transponders that provide IFF capability to distinguish friendly UAS and provide safety of flight, especially against friendly counter UAS efforts in theater.  UHF/VHF Communications relay packages will enable two-way voice communication and the ability for a UAS operator to speak directly to Air Traffic Controllers or other forces in theater.

Funds in FY 2022-2024 are required to perform future payload upgrade retrofits to provide new capability to USN NSW users.
